author: lineage.jon
title: Anime NFT Game - East Asian centric
description: Current crypto games are very Western centric. It is imperative to involve the East Asian's involvement in achieving wider adoption

f6_assessments.q0: The game is close matching the challenge seeks. I found the proposed solution is interesting because it tends to focus on Asian and allow player either using mobile or PC platform to play the game, hence it has accessibility compared to other games which most available for PC. Overall, the proposal idea is not new or unique since another proposal in this Gamers On challenge. Therefore, I recommend convincing the funder, the proposal should point out the outstanding features which make them differ from other ideas such as their UX design or the motivation to make gamers choose your game. Moreover, the challenge or risks section may require detail to measure the success and reduce the risks.
f6_assessments.q1: Firstly, the proposal is still a draft idea and there will be many features and work to develop a complete version. Regarding the team member, we haven’t got the team information yet. The author described that he had 4 years in project management and vast resource connection in IT, but he didn’t mention any previous gaming works or projects before, so I assume he doesn’t have experience with gaming development or the Cardano ecosystem. To build trust, it is critical to provide a name, positions in the proposal, a summary of previous projects/works, and expertise with the Cardano ecosystem. Secondly, after 9 months, the development of the first level prototype will be launched, but at the same time, the project will still look for a new team member to join.
f6_assessments.q2: The team is smart when asking for a small budget for each fund. I would recommend explaining how each amount will be spent. For example, the amount offered for character designers will be $6,200, so how many designers will be hired? And are they paid in an hour or monthly? On the other side, the proposal asked for funding for the prototype stage, it should focus on developing prototype detail and the method to measure the progress. However, the proposal expected a successful project is “A successful sale of the founding NFTs and expanding the team!”. Therefore, I believe more information about the successful project can concrete the audibility.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal aims are creating an Anime NFT Game called Gliese 16c. In the IdeaFest video, there’s just a brief explanation about the game itself and how it will look like, so it’s not possible to understand in full how the gameplay is going to be like, the mechanics and objectives. Some more information on this regard could be provided in the proposal text, since it’s not included in details in the IdeaFest video. The main focus of this game is the Asian community, which is, as said, not very involved with the current NFT gaming world, which is mostly western-centric. This is good to increase the gaming community of Cardano in Asia and eastern hemisphere in general. The proposal is well aligned with the challenge, and there are some KPIs to measure the impact of this proposal. The challenges and risks are only briefly mentioned, and there is no real suggestions on how to overcome them or what to do in case of partial failure, for example. I believe the proposal and game idea are good, but the proposal overall should provide more information about the whole project.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposing team presents a brief roadmap and milestones for Q2 and Q3+Q4. Is just includes high level milestones, which may be more difficult for the community to keep track of the progress. They’ve also included a Demo and Alpha versions of the game for future development, which is not included in the proposal but it’s a good indication about the direction they are going to - as, for example, they mention they will probably apply for Catalyst funds again for the Demo. The budget included to executing all of this seems to be very short and in my opinion it wouldn’t be enough to deliver the project. Even though, if they’ve included it there, they might already have analyzed it. Also, the proposer mentions that he’s the only one in the team, which is relatively risky in relation to the execution of everything, but it makes more sense related to the budget itself. I’d like to see more information about the proposer and why his background is sufficient to make this happen.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal adds information about the success of the project based on some milestones accomplishments and some KPIs related to the game adoption, which is good to measure it. Although, some information is missing about how the community is going to keep track of the progress before the project is fully delivered. It could, for example, provide monthly reports, an open repository to have the progress visible and other ways to check what’s being done. The auditability of this proposal would be much better overall if this information was included.

f6_assessments.q0:
Having an East Asian on-chain game will benefit cardano as a whole as there seem to be very few East Asian blockchain games due to the clampdown on crypto.
The proposal approach is commendable for breaking the project into smaller chunks increasing its chances of being funded.This also benefits other proposals as more funds will be available in the challenge.
There is also a good explanatory F7 presentation video provided by the proposer which helps in understanding the goals and objectives of the proposing team.
I feel the response to the potential risk and challenges are understated as many things can go wrong during game development and it will be helpful if the proposer can write a more detailed Potential risk / challenges section in the comment section so other CA can see it there(This is only a suggestion coming from a gamer) to avoid lower scores.
You can have a look at some previously funded proposals within this category as reference https://drive.google.com/file/d/193GZulHuk0zhpTrMiLhcNC4OeEMoRyIa/view
Considering all of the stated above, i am giving a 5 star as most of my concerns do not affect the positive impact of this proposal if executed to completion.
f6_assessments.q1:
The feasibility is well detailed broken down by milestones, timelines and quarters round the 12 month timeline.
The cost breakdown is detailed especially after watching the linked youtube presentation.
Verifiable links of the teams capability was provided and the team have shown experience by the way they are handling the project in little stages.this has the added benefits of burnout which can be common in indie projects(This can easily be added to potential risks/challenges).
I am giving 5 star because taking the project in chunks makes is highly achievable and funded.
f6_assessments.q2:
The provided roadmap and KPI can be used to track the project.
I am giving 5 star as all the details provided can be used to track and audit the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: It does address the challenge. The idea of targeting mostly eastern Asian market has potential. But also it is flooded with games, difficult to say if this game will stick out from the crowd. The introduction of NFTs could be something new and interesting to the market. The youtube video attached is a nice introduction to the game and shows that there is plan from the team involved.
f6_assessments.q1: At this point it is difficult to say if the proposal will succeed. Gaming market is huge and it is especially difficult for small studios (or in this case independent)  to push their game. The idea of using NFTs in the game, which is not so popular in eastern market, has potential. But how will this potential be transferred in success? If eastern market is not familiar with NFTs, how will they be drawn to play this game? As I said, potential is there but difficult to say if it will succeed or not.
f6_assessments.q2: If game kicks-off it will be easy to see how many NFTs are sold and it can be used as a metric to see the success of the game. But this will take some time to get there, and in the mean time there are certain things that can be monitored in terms of game development. The success of the proposal depends on how it will be accepted in the market, which is difficult to say at this point.

f6_assessments.q0: This is a cool idea, to try and interest the Asian gamers with this style of game.  Many game projects are not targeted for this audience and bringing them in is a great idea.  I would suggest that you should have put more of the info you put in the video into the proposal itself as I imagine many people will not take the time to peruse the video before making a decision.
f6_assessments.q1: Proposer has a fairly detailed vision and strategy to build the game, however has no team members other than themselves and has put no information on themselves other than to state that they have "4 years in Project Management, vast resource connection in IT. As an South-East Asian, and a gaming enthusiast, I know Asian game appetites."  As much as I like this idea, information here is lacking.
f6_assessments.q2: Not many metrics to audit on, but given the early stage and currently modest funding of the project this seems passable as a team is indeed required to push it further.

solution: Design a game that fits the East Asian appetite, pushing it out on mobile and PC platform as they're the most popular platforms.
